section.title: Creating a High Availability Router
section.p: You can create a highly available router.

ol.li: To create the HA router simply add the -ha True to the neutron router-create command. In this example, the router name is routerHA. $ neutron router-create routerHA -ha True
Set the gateway for the external network and add interface $ neutron router-gateway-set routerHA <ext-net-id> $ neutron router-interface-add routerHA <private_subnet_id>
Once the router, gateway and interface are created, you now have a router with high availability.

section.title: Test Router for High Availability
section.p: You can demonstrate that the router is HA by running a continuous ping from a VM instance that is running on the private network to an external network such as Googles public DNS. As the ping is running, we identify the L3 agent that is responsible for the router. Induce the failover mechanism by creating a catastrophic event like shutting down the primary routerâ€™s node. Once the node is shut down, you will see that the ping from the VM to the external network continues to run as the failover of the agents restores the ping to external network. To make sure the agent has changed, identify the agent of the same router again. You will see a different agent.

ol.li: Boot an instance on the private network $ nova boot --image <image_id> --flavor <flavor_id> --nic net_id=<private_net_id> VM1
Log into the VM using ssh with keys
Start a ping to 8.8.8.8 (Google). While pinging, make sure there is no packet loss and leave the ping running. $ ping 8.8.8.8
Check which agent is active with the router $ neutron l3-agent-list-hosting-router <router_id>
Shutdown the node where the L3 agent is alive. See
Within 10 seconds, check again to see which L3 agent is hosting the router $ neutron l3-agent-list-hosting-router <router_id>
You will see a different agent.
